reviews.review_text: I'll break down Trinity like this.  Sins (original) is an incredible game worth 60 dollars easily.  The 'Entrenchment' expansion adds starbases which are cool and pretty big game changers as well as mines. Probably worth no more than 10 dollars.  The 'Diplomacy' DLC adds envoy and envoy bonuses which are very nice to have but difficult to obtain and pointless except in big matches. I would say that's worth no more than 5.   If you're here because of a steam sale. I'd say grab Trinity so you can enjoy the full content (Or even better Sins of the Solar Empire :Rebellion) but if you're really tight for cash and the DLC are looking pricy. Just grab the original.
One of the best RTS games around.  Excellent pacing, detail, and beautiful to behold.

An epic RTS game that utilises fast expansion mechanics that could give you a tactical weakness, unlike more simply games such as the command and conquer fanchise. There are multiple different types of ships to choose from, which nearly all of them have a direct opposite that they are designed to destroy, meaning you need to learn quickly or be destroyed. However, saying that, the auto AI on targetting is second to none, as it'll target its counterpart and work together with fleets of other ships to burn down individual targets also, without the player micromanaging it. This is important as you probably won't be having a linear fight in 1 planetary orbit, as you could be defending numerous worlds at the same time! This game has the finest parts from titles like haegemonia: legions of iron, in regards to upgrades and planetary combat and then star trek armarda style fights where fleet size means nothing against fleet composition.  An example of such epic gameplay is I entered a 1v1 with the AI on normal. The AI discovered pirates, bribed them with a bounty on my head and the pirates sent a massive fleet that took me right back to my capital world for a last ditch defence. I'd made a capital ship (massive, well armoured and armed!) and a handful of frigates and managed to beat the fleet back. That then resulted in rapid expansion, putting me in a better position than I started with. Its situations like that which you won't find with other games. Highly recommend buying this!

On a personal note, I wanted to like Trinity, I really did, but I just cant find anything about it that I love enough to continue playing the game. However there was nothing that I can say is inherent bad about the game.  Over all the game is solid, graphics are legible and detailed even by todays standards. The strategy is good and simple, build lots of ships, fight your enemy, pay off pirates to not attack you, or pay them to attack someone else. The only problem that I had was that even today, this game, which was released in like 2009, still throttled my 2011 Toshiba Qosmio to the point where the over heating failsafes kicked in and shut my laptop down. I had to elevate my laptop using a couple of small boxes and use a fan to blow air at the underside of it.  While I do recommend this game I do so out of the fact that it is a good game, just not one that I found enjoyable enough to want to ever play again.

5/5 ***** Probably one of my all time favorite games. This is arguable one of the best 4X strategy games ever made. It is a real time game with turn based elements. The pace is very slow and methodical, getting rushed can be easily dealt with or avoided altogether, lol its just not really that viable to rush. If you like space games, and you love the idea of commanding literally hundreds of ships in massive interstellar battles, then this is the game for you. Just a warning though, you will want a high end PC for this. The settings allow it to be toned down for better performance on mid level machines, but it runs and looks its best on a high end rig.

I've been playing this game for a few years now, and I definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys strategy games. I love games that take place in outer space, and this game certainly does not disappoint. Despite the game looking spectacular, the system requirements are fairly low, meaning that you don't have to have a beast of a computer to run it. There are three playable factions, each catered to a specific play style. Each faction has variations of several units, unique units, and different tech trees. The game has a lot of replay value due to the number of possible map combinations. There is a lot of exploration, economics, and diplomacy, in addition to the fleet vs fleet action. The game is more about macro-management, so you don't have to order each individual ship to do a particular task, and managing a large empire with multiple fleets is easy due to this approach. The downside to the game is the lack of a single-player campaign / story mode. You have to read up the lore on your own time if you want to learn who these three factions are or why they are fighting. Other than that, I recommend this game and give it a 9/10.

I realize most people love this game. I don't like it at all. I'll preface my review by saying had I known what kind of game this was, I wouldn't have bought it. I was looking for a turn based game that was more complex than the game 'Deadlock' and less complex than 'Space Empires'. Google told me to try this game. Here are my problems with the game.  Everything costs too much money/resources. It seems you just spend hours and hours saving to be able to afford the most basic research. Almost every building requires research and once you finally get that research you'll find that you have no room for the building you need to build because every zone you conquer has a VERY small limit to how many buildings can be built in it. As well the bonuses the techs in the tech tree give are stupidly small for how much they cost. The tech tree is large but I how long I will have to for the resources to spend on research before I can get a ship that isn't complete garbage, apparently it's longer than 4 hours so I am not interested.  This game seems like it took the worst parts of Shogun 2, Age of Empires and Starcraft and threw them into a gigantic, boring, confusing game.
